Post Text: Niche ‚â† industryThis is a mistake I see a lot of founders and solopreneurs make.They try to niche down by industry.And struggle to find one that fits their solution.A niche is a specialized segment of the market for a particular service.Meaning, it's MORE than just an industry.It's whatever segment of the market works for your service.Here are some other ways to think about your niche:- company size- company stage- company service- company budget- company location- company revenue- company struggle- company industry- company structure- level of service- level of quality- personality- [add your ICP's defining attribute here]Or any combination of those.So your niche could be:Family-owned, mid-stage manufacturing companies with small or no marketing teams.OREnterprise-level tech companies with 1000+ employees struggling to create outbound sales opportunities.Industry is just one way to niche. you a real-life example.Let's say you're an energy and sustainability SaaS company.You provide a platform that allows colleges and municipalities:- track their energy usage across multiple locations- track sustainability efforts- compile all that data- provide recommendations for improvement(as well as 100 other things)Most people would say you're an energy and sustainability solution.Including consultant......followed by all of your competitors.Not a good sign.You need a category people understand.Energy and Sustainability.But you need to eliminate companies who you do NOT compete with.(aka solar panel manufacturers and sustainability consultants)And you want to eliminate companies you DO compete with.(other energy and sustainability SaaS platforms)Plus, it has to be something your ideal customers.Before they even see the platform.Don't take this step lightly.Defining the right category helps people understand what you do.And what makes you different from the competition.If you Post Text: Positioning is the art of choosing:- the category you'll play in- the unique value you'll bringYou need both in your strategy.Here's why üëáüèºYour category and the unique value you provide are tied together.Go wide on your categoryYou need a sharper unique valueGo niche on your categoryYou can have a broader unique valueIt's a balancing game.Let me give you an example.Let's say you have an energy and sustainable SaaS platform.There are two ways to play your positioning:(there are way more, but for the sake of the example, I'm using 2)Option 1:You choose Energy and Sustainability Solution as your category.It's super broad ‚Äî encompassing:- solar panel manufacturers- organizational training- energy companies- consultantsIf you play in that category, you better bring a SHARP unique value.Because you're now competing in a pretty big pool.Option 2:You choose Energy and Sustainability ERP as your category.This is super niche.It eliminates all the competition from option 1.Aligns with what your ideal customers already know.In this scenario, you have 5 competitors.So you only have to be different from 5 other companies.It's like a seesaw.Wide category = narrow differentiationNarrow category = wider differentiationThat's why choosing the category to play in is essential.Otherwise, that unique value you think you bring......might not actually be unique.Choose your category.Then, choose how you'll be different.It's a much easier way to position your business.Unless you like doing things ass-backward.Then, ignore this advice.And keep doing you, boo.‚úåüèº#shftyourbrand-----üëãüèº Hi, I'm #SassyJason.
